awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predicting and Optimizing User Comfort for Lower-limb Exoskeletons through Mutual Motor Adaptations
awd_abstract_narration:
Assistive robotic devices such as exoskeletons can be used to enhance human capabilities, help with physically-intense labor, and improve rehabilitation. User-perceived comfort is critically important for the wide-spread adoption of assistive robotic devices, yet the definition and measurement of comfort remains elusive. The research objective of this project is to systematically define, model, and optimize the comfort perceived by human users while walking with powered leg exoskeletons.  The project pursues three objectives: The first develops a model of comfort based on biosignals recorded during walking with lower limb exoskeleton robots. The second optimizes parameters of exoskeleton control based on verbalized reports of user comfort. The third optimizes exoskeleton control for comfort without direct user reporting. If successful, the project will lead to a new generation of exoskeleton devices that are more compatible with the humans they are designed to serve. This would benefit a large population of people with gait impairments, thereby advancing the national health and welfare.  Broader impacts of this work include novel, hands-on outreach activities serving underrepresented minorities in central Pennsylvania and in Dallas, Texas.

This project takes significant steps towards the development of robotic controllers that adapt continuously to each user and minimize user discomfort. This will be achieved by using neural network models to analyze and model a selected set of the users' biological signals (e.g., metabolic cost, heart rate, muscle activation, kinematics, and kinetics) to develop a novel comfort predictor, and then by creating intelligent controllers that maximize the user comfort via human-in-the-loop reinforcement learning. Human subject experiments are planned using two devices (a knee and hip device, and an ankle device) to verify that the comfort predictor can be used effectively with the optimization method.  If successful, the project could benefit a large population of people with gait impairments and those requiring robotic assistance with physically-intense labor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to systematically define, model, and optimize the comfort perceived by human subjects, particularly users walking with powered lower-limb exoskeletons. The team achieved the objectives of assessing body stresses by analyzing and modeling biological signals detected by wearables on the body. Our works address the challenges of using on-body sensors to acquire objective signals for human-device interactions. 

Intellectual Merits

The intellectual merits include a systematic method to analyze comfort perception by physical sensors interfaced between the human body parts and the machine as well as new noninvasive sensor research. Objective physiological signals, recorded wirelessly by sEMG (surface electromyography) electrodes, pulse and heart rate sensors, force sensors and strain sensors were analyzed with 3-D images acquired by multiple infrared and optical cameras for kinetics analysis. Robotic exoskeleton control parameters were adaptively adjusted with the physiological sensor signals to minimize stress during walking. Noninvasive radio-frequency resonator sensors based on rigid and flexible substrates were investigated to detect skin characteristics, related to whole-body hydration levels and changes in blood vessels. The sensors were tested and characterized in phantoms and on human bodies demonstrating their capability of continuous detection of physiological conditions. Simulations and experiments validated the scientific principles of sensing and the parameter variations among individuals' physical conditions. Machine learning methods were investigated for physiological condition prediction from real-time sensor data. The works demonstrated the feasibility of utilizing noninvasive sensors to track physical stresses and use the signals to adaptively adjust the parameters in a feedback loop.  

Broader Impacts

The systematic method for assessing human physical conditions can be applied to various applications benefiting the development of wearables and assistive technologies for patients with mobility challenges. Research on noninvasive radio-frequency sensors has enabled several new applications due to their flexibility and small formfactors, high sensitivity to water content, and wearability, including whole-body hydration monitoring, blood vessel identification and monitoring, subcutaneous tumor identification, cancerous tumor detection and agriculture product monitoring. The potential of utilizing the conformal miniature sensors for sensing dielectric properties of materials is broad. Their uses on fitness and healthcare can significantly benefit the well-being of large populations, particularly for the elderly and children, with broad societal impacts. Female Ph.D. and undergraduate students have been mentored through the project. Undergraduate and high-school students from underrepresented groups participated in the research during summer periods. Demonstrations and presentations were conducted in a local high-school and a regional science and engineering fair which served students in the underrepresented groups. The research outcomes have been disseminated in peer-reviewed international journal and conference publications and presentations. Additionally, a provisional U.S. patent has been filed for potential commercialization opportunities.
